text: I remember some embereños here being headphone connoiseurs
I want something quality, but not willing to go beyond that £150 mark
suggestions? :sun_with_face:

I don’t know about connoisseur but I got some first gen Beoplay H6s for around that price when Amazon had a crazy sale on them and I think you can still find them around that price as the new generation is out now. I’m by no means an expert but I’ve really liked them and would recommend :+1:
<@U047GTU64> I think <@U04BD6KB1> is the headphone connoiseur

I think I was part of that, I got some Plantronics Backbeat Pros off of Amazon for £120 or so, sounds good, ANC and bluetooth enabled, transport controls and suchlike on the cups. Some of the gimmicky features are a bit ropy. It's supposed to auto-pause when you take the things off, but that unilaterally stopped working after about three months, I also get brutal bluetooth interference at the east end of platform 7 at Highbury & Islington for some reason
I'm happy with them though, very handy on the go
home listening you'd probably want some open-backed boys, better for long listening periods although by definition there's less noise cancelling going on

<@U047GTU64> one aspect to consider is where you're sourcing your content ... specifically do you listen to most of your music via a phone, a laptop, or a hifi system (or other analogue source). I guess the last option is pretty much being phased out these days. :slightly_smiling_face: The reason I make this distinction is that these days phone listening is starting to force the wireless headphone onto you. Maybe that's what you want anyway (the convenience is nice) but from a fidelity standpoint the thing to bear in mind is that besides material design the biggest difference in quality if the digital-to-analogue converter built into the wireless can. If you're listening to music primarily off your laptop you can buy really good d-to-a's at a good price but the headphone manufacturers are still getting a lot of extra margin from packaging up the d-to-a benefits in their products. This is no different than what the manufacturers did in the 80's and 90's with high end CD players where the quality difference was primarily that of a good quality d-to-a but in today's world the margin is even greater because the true cost of the d-to-a is so low now.
The good news is that _going wireless_ not only adds convenience but can also mean substantially greater fidelity from all digital sources than you're probably used to getting.

If however, you are listening on laptop primarily (and your phone still has an audio jack) ... buy a d-to-a converter (about the size of a USB stick and less than £100) and anything you plug into will sound noticeably better.
you can then skimp on the cans themselves. There are a mid-priced set of cans from V-MODA that might be a really nice option.
Ooh this sounds like a good convo, <@U04BD6KB1> would you be able to recommend a good d-to-a, looking for something with a good price to quality balance
yeah i've been really happy with the Audioquest DragonFly
The highest price one is not needed, so save yourself the money
the two latest ones are lower powered so work off the audio jack of a phone but if you're using a laptop you can just go with the older model
that looks great, thanks!
<http://www.audioquest.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/dragonfly-spec-sheet-darktheme.pdf>
I have the 1.2 and the Red (I'm a snob)
but really the 1.2 is completely fine, red is not needed for anyone but pure snobs
i see that the 1.2 is discontinued now ... to bad but I bet you can get on ebay
if I were still in the UK i'd sell you mine for the price of a good beer :wink:
as I use the red all the time and don't need both
but more and more I have switched to wireless can, I love the Sennheiser Momentum II's but they're expensive
That Dragonfly Black looks good and doesn’t seem to be bad price either :+1:
you'll love the sound difference
another thing you can use a good d-to-a for is driving your desktop's speakers
I hope you’re working in Audio sales :wink:
again that area is also moving wireless but not nearly as fast
still the premium for the d-to-a seems lower for desktop
ha. thanks but no commission checks yet.
ok, time for my morning coffee. happy trails.

text: for the record, I decided to drop noice cancelation and I bought AKG Y50BT and they are amazing for the price: <https://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_sb_noss_1?url=search-alias%3Delectronics&field-keywords=akg+y50bt>
I had to renounce to noise cancellation but sound quality is very good
noise isolation is good enough
i find that they look a bit weird when you're wearing them
those?
yeah
they have an angle looks awkward when it sits - on my ears at least :smile:
I dunno, my only complain is that when you fold them the on/off button can be pressed by the other hearcup
yeah - not that big of a deal though
I can't count the number of times I've turned them by mistake
i ended up spending over-spending a bit and going for the Bose QC35. The noice cancellation is incredible
yeah, the price tag of around 250 was the deal breaker for me
I also recommend Bose QC35 if you want ANC, I've tried other models and none of them are as comfortable
I decided that my ears don't worth that much
especially if you also want wireless
best sounding were problably the Beoplay H6, not wireless and no noise cancellation, but the sound is sublime
I wouldn't go wired in 2017
with devices removing their jacks in the next years

true, although at the moment I haven't been satisfied 100% with the wireless solutions available. They either sound good and are too heavy or they are comfortable but not very good in terms of audio quality.
I'm sure they will improve a lot now that Apple has removed the mini jack from the iphone though
i'd second the not going wireless in 2017 argument
<@U0C5RUAQ4> you second *not going* wireless or *not going* wired?
I found bluetooth very convenient, specially because I tended to break my headsets because the cable was rolled in the arm of my chair
and when I move I pull it
the cable was detachable but still
yeah that's a classic I do it all the time
it ended up being a killer after 60 of those hard pulls
not going wired :smile:
